cards.notes:
Valid targets include barrier statues, several vehicles, equipment, mana rocks, compulsory evacuation device, and a number of golems and constructs, notably including Machine King Prototype and Lost Guardian, which all buff each other. The Barrier statues are generally the most impactful hits, with Heavens and Drought being the only real duds.

The Flashback ability is uncommon in this set, but it enables this card to provide additional value later in the game and help artifact-heavy decks get over the edge.

This card is most useful in colorless, azorius decks, and equipment-heavy decks, and is expected to be passed by most other players due to a lack of good targets.

cards.notes: Jawnie's recommendation is to drop it to 3 mana for +3/+0 and equip 3. I recognize this might be stronger mechanically, but I also feel like it lacks the presence that Axe of Despair has if it's giving +3/+0 instead of +4/+0. +4/+0 feels like "a lot" in MTG in the same way that +1000 ATK feels like a lot in Yugioh. I could drop it to 3 and have it give +4/+0, but I'm afraid it might be too strong then, so I'm leaving it here for now, with playtesting being what determines if or how it changes.

cards.notes:
A powerful and impactful threat with both flash and lifelink while have a 3/2 statline, for 3, plus the opportunity for recursion. This card seems pushed. Originally it returned the creature to the top of the library, which seemed a lot less powerful, but I received feedback that that was "too weak" for giving up a draw. I don't know where this card really sits at this point. I want to have some lifegain in the set because I think it's important to balance out paying life for other cards, but maybe this card isn't it.

For now I'm removing the lifelink and changing the recursion to only work on creatues with mana value three or less. This should make it a lot more reasonable in power level.

In terms of archetypes, I think this card is most in-line with the golgari gameplan. The flash is very relevant for blocking with a creature with divide, and also allows you to flash it in as a blocker potentially. It also seems strong in rakdos, which may run a lot of smaller creatures for an aggro gameplan and sacrifice a lot of its own stuff. Orzhov it feels much more niche, sometimes giving value but often not as impactful as another card might be. In dimir it could be good some of the time, but I think it is not as good as many other options (the flash is the only saving grace). Certainly still a strong card though.

cards.notes: This card is most in line with the dimir archetype. You will generally use it to search for a removal spell, which can then be used to deal with an opponent's threat and maintain control over the game. The defense position stats allow you to play it on turn 1 to slow down an opponent's initial aggro gameplan, and then sac it as a blocker later to get the removal spell you need to deal with whatever killed it. The alternative mode, as a 1/1 sometimes unblockable, allows you to get in a little bit of extra damage in lategame situations where you might not have something you want to search for, or where that extra damage is more impactful, potentially allowing you to close out the game. Staple a powerful aura, give it a weapon, or hit it with a combat trick to get even more damage in—benefiting rakdos strategies or orzhov in the right situations. This card has the lowest level of synergy with golgari, which is more of a grindy creature-control archetype, that looks to continue bringing its resources back again and again. It can still have some impact there as a tutor for a removal spell, but other uncommon creatures could be more in line with the game plan.

cards.notes: This is a Golgari staple. It basically has escape 2B, exile one creature, except it comes into play tapped. The wither makes it a powerful and challenging threat, always having an impact on the board even if it dies. This also makes it really great for dimir, with dimir's self-mill giving it plenty of material to gobble up and keep coming back to pester an opponent with more -1/-1 counters on their creatures. Rakdos is less exciting about this creature, but still likes it, and it should see less play in Orzhov, as it doesn't really work with their gameplan at all.

cards.notes:
Benevolent Bodyguard 2, electric boogaloo. Benevolent Bodyguard is an iconic card from my early days of playing MTG, this card is a shoutout to it, although it gives hexproof and indestructible instead of protection.

This creature offers a decent body while also giving an instant-speed reaction you can use to save a creature on your side of the board.

Whether or not the ability should also require tapping is an open question, if it does then it limits this creature's effectiveness significantly, because it cannot be used for protection until it loses summoning sickness. For now I'll have it not tap, because that feels more in line with other effects of this type in MTG.

cards.notes: This creature is meant to be powerful both for orzhov and dimir, with the dimir often wanting to mill her to get the surveil and life gain every turn, and orzhov wanting to use her in their flood-the-board-with-flyers strategy. She also has some relevance for rakdos as a way to get some lifegain to stay in the game while being as aggressive as possible, or as a flyer to get a few final hits in over blockers that can't fly or reach.

cards.rules_text:
Flash, riot [i](This creature enters with your choice of a +1/+1 counter or haste.)[/i]
The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you, prevent that damage. If damage is prevented this way, Eco, Mystical Spirit of the Forest deals damage equal to the damage prevented this way to the source's controller.

Fusion {RW}{BR} – An Elemental and a Warrior [i](You may cast this spell from outside the game or from your command zone for its Fusion cost by sacrificing or discarding the noted fusion material cards.)[/i]
Flash, riot
When Charubin the Fire Knight enters, destroy target creature an opponent controls.

Flash, defender
When Barrier Statue of the Heavens enters or is turned face-up, for each creature you control create a 1/1 white Angel creature token with flying, then creatures you control get +0/+4 until end of turn.

Menace, vigilance
When Demise, King of Armageddon enters, if it wasn't cast, you may pay 8 life. If you do, destroy all other nonland permanents.
[i]Channel[/i] – {B}{B}{B}, Discard Demise: Destroy target creature.
cards.notes:
Demise is the mono-black legendary mythic creature. He is a ritual monster, and has his greatest value come into play when he is played using his corresponding ritual. You can also get his value by recurring/cheating him onto the board with cards like Give and Take, Barrier Statue of the Abyss, Monster Reborn, The Grave of Enkindling, St. Joan, and the Creator. All of these are rare or mythic with the exception of Give and Take, which is at common but comes at the disadvantage of giving your opponent Demise (while also paying the 8 life).

I think Demise is most playable in Rakdos and Dimir, with some play being possible in Golgari and Orzhov as well, but not being as efficient.

Demise is a massive creature, and honestly might need to have more of a drawback when just cast for his mana cost. Although, 8 mana does make him incredibly slow to play. Most large black creatures, and demons especially, in MTG have some kind of drawback. His drawback is currently optional, and only happens when he enters having not been cast. This could be a cadnidate for adjustment.

cards.rules_text:
Ritual 8 – {2}{B}{B}{B}{B} [i](You may sacrifice creatures and discard creature cards whose mana values add up to 8 or more and pay {2}{B}{B}{B}{B} instead of this card's mana cost.)[/i]
Search your library for a black card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle. Then if you paid the Ritual cost put a card named Demise, King of Armageddon from your hand onto the battlefield tapped. Otherwise, you gain 8 life.
cards.notes:
This is black's tutor ritual, which also gives a bunch of lifegain. This card is amazing in any black deck, but shines the most in control decks.

I'd rate as:
Dimir > Rakdos > Orzhov > Golgari. Golgari likes this the least because they're chump blocking the most, so they are the least in need of lifegain, and have fewer amazing cards to tutor for, generally. Tutoring for a mythic bomb will always be good though, of course.

cards.rules_text:
Emerge {4}{B} [i](You may cast this spell by sacrificing a creature and paying the emerge cost reduced by that creature's mana value.)[/i]
Flash, flying
When Dragon Seeker enters or is turned face-up, destroy target non-black, non-artifact creature. If it was a dragon, draw a card.
cards.notes:
Modeled after Dark Hatchling, Dalek Drone, Dakmor Lancer, and Black Dragon. This could be modified to destroy a creature an opponent controls that was dealt damage this turn, as another way to adjust its effect to be more conditional, and to make the flash feel more relevant to its play-pattern (that would probably replace the non-black & non-artifact restriction).

This creature is strong in Orzhov, as it gives as way to destroy enemy flyers, while also giving you a flyer. It is also strong in rakdos. This creature has some use in dimir as a way to control the board, and is least impactful in golgari (though removal is always strong, tbf).

This card excels against decks that play dragons. Dragons in my set are all in red and blue, so this guy is often a really strong play against izzet players.

cards.notes:
This card can be played for its discounted cost when a player reanimates a creature, when they emerge a creature, or when they cast a creature for another alternative cost. It's especially good against token decks that do one of these things and then flood the board in the same turn, but can also be effective against aggro decks.

Overall it's a really solid piece of premium removal, you'll be happy even if it hits a single creature most of the time.
